frameDefinitions: This is an abstract frame for acts performed by sentient beings.
An Agent or Cause causes an Entity to change, either in its category membership or in terms of the value of an Attribute.
An Agent causes a Patient to be affected, sometimes by a particular Means or by use of an Instrument.
A Cause (or associated Actor) causes an ongoing Process to temporarily stop.
An Agent causes a Theme to move from a Source, along a Path, to a Goal.
frameExamples: Our storylines follows the saga outlined by the Ultima Series, but we have <t>modified</t> it in order to make our writing more cohesive.
A professional dishwasher doesn't <t>do</t> dishes with a rag anymore!
She <t>threw</t> her shoes into the dryer .
listRoleDefinitions: This role identifies the <fen>Act</fen> that the <fen>Agent</fen> performs intentionally.
The <fen>Agent</fen> performs the intentional act.
This role identifies the time when the Agent acts intentionally.
This role identifies the place where the intentional act occurs.
The sentient entity that effects a change in the <fen>Entity</fen>.
The category of which the <fen>Entity</fen> is a member before the <fen>Agent</fen> causes a change.
The category that the <fen>Entity</fen> belongs to after it has undergone the change.
The value that the <fen>Attribute</fen> assumes as a result of the change that the <fen>Entity</fen> is caused to undergo.
The value that the <fen>Attribute</fen> has before the change takes place.
A characteristic of the <fen>Entity</fen> for which a value can be assigned or determined by calculation, measurement , or observation.
The abstract or concrete thing or situation that the <fen>Agent</fen> causes to change.
An event that causes a change in the <fen>Entity</fen>.
The time at which the change of the <fen>Entity</fen> is caused.
The location where the change of the <fen>Entity</fen> is caused.
This role identifies the act that the <fen>Agent</fen> performs intentionally.
The conscious entity, generally a person, that performs the intentional act that affects the <fen>Patient</fen>.
Patient is the entity acted on and that may, but need not, undergo a change.
This role identifies the time when the <fen>Agent</fen> intentionally affects the <fen>Patient</fen>.
This role identifies the place where the <fen>Agent</fen> performs the intentional act.
A force, process, or event that produces an effect.
Agents in a joint or reciprocal action (e.g. exchange)
A positive or negative evaluation of the Phenomenon.
An entity which participates in a <fen>Cause</fen>, perhaps volitionally and perhaps not.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.
A force, process, or event that produces the interruption.
The <fen>Process</fen> goes into a paused state due to the <fen>Cause</fen> or <fen>Actor</fen>.
An entity which participates in a <fen>Cause</fen>, perhaps volitionally and perhaps not, but effectively causing the interruption.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the interruption occurs.
Where the interruption takes place.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the one whose action causes the motion of a <fen>Theme</fen>.  The <fen>Agent</fen> is generally realized as the External Argument.
The role <fen>Theme</fen> is generally an NP Object.
The role <fen>Source</fen> is the starting point of motion.
The role <fen>Path</fen> is any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor <fen>Goal</fen>.
The role <fen>Goal</fen> is the point at which the <fen>Theme</fen> ends up as a result of the motion.

The role <fen>Area</fen> is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular or not to consist of a single, linear path. Locative setting adjuncts may also be assigned this frame element.
<fen>Cause</fen> marks expressions that indicate some non-intentional, typically non-human, force that causes the <fen>Theme</fen> to be set in motion.
A resultant state that the <fen>Theme</fen> is in at the end of its motion.
A previous state that the <fen>Theme</fen> was in before the beginning of its motion.
The time at which the motion of the <fen>Theme</fen> occurs.
The <fen>Place</fen> is the general area that provides a setting for a specific motion (with <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen>, or <fen>Goal</fen>).
listRoleExamples: <fex>We</fex> have not yet acted .
<fex>The system administrator</fex> changed the value from 'KDE' to 'GNOME', and then restarted the system.
Her time with the Healer Craft has changed her <fex>from a shy, nervous young girl</fex> into a confident (almost) young woman
The radical message of the cross transformed Saul of Tarsus and changed him from a persecutor of Christians <fex>to a tender believer</fex>.
We changed the size from 8 1/2x11 <fex>to a larger 11 x 17</fex> and gave it a complete graphical makeover.
My dad changed his hair color <fex>from red</fex>  to blue today.
We changed <fex>the price</fex> from $1.26 to $1.27 per pint.
The recent terrorist attacks had changed <fex>the political climate</fex>.
<fex>Major technological innovations</fex> changed the social and economic conditions.
He changed it <fex>after David Bowie told him that only twerps have the same first and last name</fex>.
<fex>In his own room</fex> he had modified nothing.
A professional dishwasher does <fex>dishes</fex> one at a time.
<fex>The wind</fex> made the door rattle.
<fex>That one stone</fex>, apparently, caused the avalanche that engulfed square miles of forest.
<fex>Leaving the page after you've clicked 'Download'</fex> will interrupt the transfer.
Leaving the page after you've clicked 'Download' will interrupt <fex>the transfer</fex>.
In such cases <fex>the server</fex> will automatically interrupt the process.
<fex>Pat</fex> threw the china at the wall.
Pat threw <fex>the china</fex> at the wall.
Pat dragged the box <fex>out of the cupboard</fex>.
I pushed the trolley <fex>along the street</fex>.
Kim threw the cat <fex>into the garden</fex>.
Kim pushed the lawnmower <fex>around the garden</fex>.
<fex>The storm</fex> tossed the sailor from the boat
The fireman dragged the injured driver <fex>clear</fex>
Paul pulled Fran upright <fex>from her sitting position</fex>.
We shoved half of the cargo overboard <fex>on the 29th</fex>.
